author: The Telegraph
title: Activities for all in Western Australia
text: Across all four corners of Western Australia you are guaranteed extraordinary encounters – from swimming with whale sharks at Ningaloo Reef to feeding wild dolphins in Monkey Mia, from outback adventures in the Kimberley region to the heady combination of towering forests, surf and wine in the south west. Many of these iconic experiences can only be found in Western Australia. Only here can you reach, via a short swim, the World Heritage-listed Ningaloo Marine Park, home to the world’s largest fringing reef. Nowhere else on this planet can you access such a large coral reef so easily. Perth – Australia’s sunniest city Australia’s sunniest capital city, Perth, enjoys more than 3,000 hours of sunshine a year, and contains all the essential ingredients for a great holiday – a remarkable 19 city beaches, plenty of nightlife, outdoor dining, bustling markets, the world’s largest inner-city park and amazing marine adventures. Locals here enjoy a relaxed outdoor lifestyle; follow suit and take a day trip to the nearby port city of Fremantle at the mouth of the Swan River, or take a short ferry ride to Rottnest Island – a relaxed, car-free escape with 63 beaches for you to enjoy. Nature with a gourmet twist Australia’s South West boasts a perfect combination of travel experiences. Discover towering forests, whale watching, fine food and wine, and beaches galore. The Margaret River region boasts world-class wineries, top surfing, inspiring walking tracks, horse riding through the bush and mountains of delicious local produce. In the forests of karri and tingle trees south of Pemberton, you can look out over the towering timbers – an amazing experience. The stunning coastline from Denmark to Albany is dotted with coves and bays, dramatic cliffs and squeaky-clean white sand beaches stretching as far as the eye can see. Surf’s up: Cottesloe Beach in Perth True outback adventures Australia’s North West is home to one of the country’s last true wilderness areas, known as the Kimberley. A mysterious place of raw nature – with ancient red rock gorges, rugged ranges, cattle stations the size of European countries, and an indigenous culture dating back tens of thousands of years. Get there from the exotic pearling town of Broome, where you can experience sunset camel rides along the breathtaking 22km stretch of soft white sand known as Cable Beach. The northern gateway to the Kimberley is Kununurra, where you can easily access Purnululu National Park, home to the World Heritage-listed Bungle Bungle Range. Road trip heaven Australia’s Golden Outback is a region of startling contrasts, from red dirt to rugged coast, and is steeped in the history and legends of its 19th-century gold-mining pioneers. This part of Western Australia is also home to the geological marvel of Wave Rock, which is also accessible from Perth. Don’t miss the unusual attraction created by British sculptor Antony Gormley (Angel of the North) at Lake Ballard, north of Kalgoorlie – he created one of his most striking works with 51 life-sized silhouettes dotted on a salt lake, forming the largest outdoor gallery on Earth. A great self-drive destination, on your way, you can stay in hospitable farmstays or try camping out under the stars.
